- Generic has no records in AgeRating table either, it uses the complete set of PEGI age ratings, but for ageRatingID 55 it shows a 12+ icon, i.e. when PEGI shows an exclamation point icon Generic shows “12+”.

Replace all our tasks by post_request_task now that it's a separate lib (bug 1241071)

post-request-task was extracted to zamboni and published in a separate lib. One
important change from before is that it only queues tasks when a request has been
started, which means there is nothing special to do anymore to launch tasks from
a management command or a django shell.

Thanks to this change I modified all our tasks to be post_requests_tasks as there
is no drawback and the added benefit is huge.

Some tests had to be updated to either delay their indexing tasks or reindex after
they did some modifications that aren't automatically triggering reindexes. We used
to not see those because the indexing was delayed or not happening at all in some
cases.

Show a confirmation before attaching an IARC Certificate

Per spec : "present the ratings information to the developer and ask if this is the cert they want to use."

amputate restframework metadata listing

Django REST Framework 3.x provides metadata about a view in the OPTIONS
response by default. Unfortunately this includes all valid choices for
foreign-key fields, so some requests were producing all apps and all
users as part of the output. We remove this field introspection entirely.

However, the test itself depends on the LISTED_STATUSES constant.  We could test against UNREVIEWED_STATUS, but that means we are just relying on the correctness of one constant over another.

Very cool.

But at first look through I would vote for the magical category. Addon.objects.create(type=amo.ADDON_WEBAPP) returning a different object, a WebApp looks a real WTF for someone looking at this later on. A more explicit "create_addon_from_type(type=amo.ADDON_WEBAPP)" is more typing, more verbose, but much more easily traceable.

The goal for this is not just to fix Addon.objects.create but Addon.objects.get and other methods coming from the AddonManager. I want the ORM to give me a Webapp instead of an Addon when the row I'm pulling is a webapp.
Make an AddonResolve class maybe? I'm just thinking of something more explicit for later on - following the crazed psychopath rule.

Last point, what if you want to get Addons, but be sure never to get a WebApp back? If I ask for a WebApp, i'll get a WebApp, if I ask for Addon i'll get and Addon or a WebApp. Would hate to have a Addon.objects.never_give_me_a_webapp method.

I'm trying to treat these as objects that know what they need to do to themselves. I don't want Addon.save to mess with a Webapp's slug column, I want Webapp.save to mess with the app_slug column. We could make an `AddonOrWebapp` class that's really explicit, but that doesn't make for pretty code. `Webapp` inherits from `Addon` so you shouldn't need to care which one you have.

Also, I'm trying to change as little code as possible. Primarily because I'm lazy, but also because adding special cases leads to more bugs later.

Furthermore, the [Liskov Substition Principle](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liskov_substitution_principle) states that, in a computer program if S is a subtype of T, then objects of type T may be replaced with objects of type S (i.e., objects of type S may be substitutes for objects of type T), without altering any of the desirable properties of that program (correctness, task performed, etc.).

If we order by RAND() here, we'll get all the randomness we need from the db.  The downside is that the RAND() query will be cached, so followup calls will not be so random.  Once the query goes out of cache (after however long the timeout is), we'll get a new randomized list.

That's the tradeoff.  What do you think?

Up until now there's been no reason we can't increase our cache time, right?  (ie. I think we have perfect caching so far?)  

I don't mind a cached RAND() since with a front end cache people aren't going to see much changing anyway.  I don't want it to be cached for a really long time if we up our cache time though.  Can we set specific cache times for a single element?
Adding explicit timeouts is one of my bugs for this release.  It will let us jack up the default timeouts but keep the list pages reasonably fresh.

+        addon = addons[0] if addons.exists() else None
review_comments.body:
This ends up doing 2 queries... one for the `exists()` which looks like a "SELECT 1 FROM ..." in SQL, and then one to get the obj. It'd be more efficient (and to me, clearer) to do the following. It is more lines but 1 less query.

```
try:
    addon = Addon.objects.get(guid=guid)
except Addon.DoesNotExist:
    addon = None
```

+
+class LazyAttribute(object):
+
+    def __init__(self, f, *args, **kw):
+        self.f = f
+        self.args = args
+        self.kw = kw
+
+    def execute(self):
+        return self.f(*self.args, **self.kw)
+
+
+class FactoryBro(object):
+
+    @staticmethod
+    def __new__(cls, **kw):
+        return cls.build(**kw)
+
+    @classmethod
+    def construct(cls, **kw):
+        data = {}
+        for k, v in inspect.getmembers(cls):
+            if (k == 'Meta' or (k[:2] == '__' and k[-2:] == '__') or
+                inspect.ismethod(v)):
+                continue
+            data[k] = v.execute() if isinstance(v, LazyAttribute) else v
+        data.update(kw)
+        return data
+
+    @classmethod
+    def build(cls, **kw):
+        """Returns an object instance without saving to the DB."""
+        return cls.Meta.model(**cls.construct(**kw))
+
+    @classmethod
+    def create(cls, **kw):
+        """Returns an object instance after saving to the DB."""
+        return cls.Meta.model.objects.create(**cls.construct(**kw))
+
+

+        class User(object):

+
Privileged app
+
+ A privileged app has been approved by the Firefox OS + Marketplace using a special process.     • +

+

A certified app must be + approved for a device by the OEM or carrier in order to have + this implicit approval to use critical APIs. The following is + the CSP for a certified app, which is slightly different from + the CSP for a privileged app: +

+                                  status=amo.STATUS_PENDING)
+            .query(or_=name_only_query(search_form.cleaned_data['q'].lower()))

+        reviewers = []
+        for theme in themes:
+            try:

     cat_form = None

review_comments.body:
I don't know the answers to these but I'm thinking about them now...

For packaged apps that have multiple versions... if I have my app and version features tied to version 1.0 and upload version 2.0 which is still pending review, the edit form is going to show the features tied to version 2.0 b/c it's the latest version.

On uploading version 2.0 am I presented with the app features form again to check which features my new version requires? If so, do we default to the prior version's features being checked off (which seems friendly)?

If version 2.0 now requires MMS (e.g.) but version 1.0 didn't, I would think we don't want to "activate" the version 2.0 feature requirements until it is published. Which means this devhub edit form should use `current_version` which is the latest published version. At least I think it should otherwise we might as well put the `ForeignKey` on the `addon` table and not track them against `version`. But if version 1.0 doesn't require MMS and my device has no MMS I'd still want to be able to search and install it before version 2.0 is published, which means we need to be careful how we handle this.

This is kinda ugly and painful.

I don't know if shoving it in a manifest helps? Although I can see the similarity if we consider how we handle the name in the manifest.

I think we just need to be clear that editing this info is tied to a specific version. Do we allow devs to edit this info after it is public already? I'd think so right? and it also makes sense they would edit it for pending review versions.

I think that changes the UI quite a bit however.

>>> import email

... header2: yolo

...

+from email import message_from_string
+from email.utils import parseaddr
+
+import commonware.log

+
+from access.models import Group
+from access import acl

+

+
+
+class ThreadObjectPermission(object):
+    """
+    Class for determining user permissions on a thread.
+    """
+
+    def check_acls(self, acl_type):
+        """
+        Check ACLs.
+        """
+        user = self.user_profile
+        obj = self.thread_obj
+        if acl_type == 'moz_contact':
+            return user.email in obj.addon.mozilla_contact.split(',')
+        elif acl_type == 'admin':
+            return acl.action_allowed_user(user, 'Admin', '%')
+        elif acl_type == 'reviewer':
+            return acl.action_allowed_user(user, 'Apps', 'Review')
+        elif acl_type == 'senior_reviewer':
+            return acl.action_allowed_user(user, 'Apps', 'ReviewEscalated')
+        else:
+            raise 'Invalid ACL lookup.'
+
+        return False
+
+    def user_has_permission(self, thread, profile):
+        """
+        Check if the user has read/write permissions on the given thread.
+
+        Developers of the add-on used in the thread, users in the CC list,
+        and users who post to the thread are allowed to access the object.
+
+        Moreover, other object permissions are also checked agaisnt the ACLs
+        of the user.
+        """
+        self.thread_obj = thread
+        self.user_profile = profile
+        user_post = CommunicationNote.objects.filter(author=profile,
+            thread=thread)
+        user_cc = CommunicationThreadCC.objects.filter(user=profile,
+            thread=thread)
+
+        if user_post.exists() or user_cc.exists():
+            return True
+
+        # User is a developer of the add-on and has the permission to read.
+        user_is_author = profile.addons.filter(pk=thread.addon_id)
+        if thread.read_permission_developer and user_is_author.exists():
+            return True
+
+        if thread.read_permission_reviewer and self.check_acls('reviewer'):
+            return True
+
+        if (thread.read_permission_senior_reviewer and self.check_acls(
+            'senior_reviewer')):
+            return True
+
+        if (thread.read_permission_mozilla_contact and self.check_acls(
+            'moz_contact')):
+            return True
+
+        if thread.read_permission_staff and self.check_acls('admin'):
+            return True
+
+        return False
+
+
+class CommEmailParser():
